cross-border crime.
Does the Commission consider that this type of
cross-border investigation permit has any foundation in the current
legal basis for Europol and/or Schengen cooperation? Can other Member
States be required to carry out similar cross-border investigations

in return?

2070,9,556,en,Poles in top-level management posts within the Commission,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

Spain 26, Italy 27, to name but the largest 'old' Member States. What
is the situation today, following the enlargement, as regards the
participation of Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovakia and

the other 'new' Member States?

2077,9,592,en,Electronic bugging of MEPs' offices,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

office in Belfast, and the British media reports that an admission
has been made that this device was placed with the authorisation of
British Intelligence.
Does the Council think that Member States acting in
such a manner are showing due regard for democratic principles and
the integrity of this institution? Does the Council accept that the
constituency offices of Members of this House merit the same respect
as offices based in the institutions? Will the Council give its
opinion on the ethics of a listening device being planted inside
offices that I use and also contact the British Government about this

",2006-10-17,draft,question
2055,9,588,en,Education exchanges,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

(A6-0256/2005) the European Parliament 'Welcomed the recent signing
by the Commission and the Indian Government of an agreement under
which the former is offering one thousand bursaries (33 million euro)
to enable Indian students to attend European universities under the
Erasmus Mundus programme, .... noted that the Indian Council for
Cultural Relations is offering opportunities for European students to
attend universities in India, but calls for greater interest to be
shown in this so as to make a more active contribution to
consolidating the foundations of the strategic partnership.'
Could the Commission give an update as to the
current implementation of these proposals, with specific reference to
collaboration in science and technology?
Does the Commission believe that professional and
business exchanges could also be beneficial, both for cross-cultural
understanding and the promotion of a two-way flow of information?
And does the Commission have any plans to replicate
the success of the Executive Training Programme - People to People
Exchange - that exists with Japan and Korea by extending the

programme to India, with the appropriate funding?

",2005-10-30,draft,question
2060,9,581,en,Linguistic diversity in the European Union	,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html
<style type=""text/css"">
@page { size: 8.27in 11.69in
TD P { margin-bottom: 0in }
P { margin-bottom: 0.08in }
</style>
Within the European Union there are languages with a
centuries-old history which are neither national nor official EU
languages but which nonetheless often have many speakers living in
different regions in a variety of Member States. In those regions,
such languages sometimes enjoy official status and in certain cases
they have a number of speakers, a literary tradition and a vitality
comparable to those of national languages which enjoy official EU
status, even though the latter may actually have only a similar or
even a smaller number of speakers.
In view of the fact that respect for linguistic
diversity is one of the EU's democratic and cultural foundations (as
acknowledged in Article 22 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights: 'The
Union shall respect cultural, religious and linguistic diversity')
and since - in accordance with the EU's values - it would therefore
be wrong to discriminate against a language merely on the grounds
that it is not spoken throughout a Member States, does the Council
not think that the EU should take greater account of the realities of
such languages?
The Spanish Government has already submitted a
Memorandum calling for the language arrangements within the EU
institutions to be amended in order to accommodate Spain's
co-official languages. What attitude is the Council likely to adopt

in response to such a request?

greatly facilitated communications between people. However,
scientific views are occasionally published which have alarmed public
opinion about the possible consequences for human health of using
mobile phones.

public is correctly and responsibly informed, will the Commission
say:
Has it drawn up a scientific study investigating
thoroughly whether and to what extent radiation from mobile phones
affects human health?

does it intend to take some initiative to promote the correct use of

",1992-02-06,draft,question
2056,9,560,en,European aid to combat forest fires,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html
<style type=""text/css"">

TD P { margin-bottom: 0in }

In recent years a growing number of fires have
occurred in the warmest regions of southern Europe, some produced by
natural causes, but most caused by carelessness or started
deliberately. The greenhouse effect and the consequent warming of
some areas of the planet is making the situation worse. During this
summer, in Andalucia (Spain) alone, more than 42 000 hectares have
been burned and, regrettably, this will not be the final figure for
the year. The EU already makes provision for aid for the prevention
of forest fires, but needs to act as a matter of urgency to restore
the damaged areas.
Given the problems of desertification caused by such
fires, will the Commission allocate specific budgetary appropriations
in 2005 in order to assist the recovery and reafforestation of areas

destroyed by fire?

",1988-05-24,draft,question
2061,9,583,en,The borders of the European Union,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

The countries and peoples of the European Union and
potential candidates for membership should be informed about plans
for future enlargement over at least the next 30 years. Future EU
Member States should be involved in the formation of an efficient
economic system and communications systems and energy and supply
networks in order not to incur unnecessary additional accession
costs. This will require a clearer definition of the conditions for
accession to the European Union and of the EU's borders, in
accordance with the expectations of the Member States (e.g. energy
security). A natural EU border would appear to be one that follows
the borders of countries all or part of whose territory is in the
continent of Europe and which have an interest in becoming EU Member
States. Such an approach would safeguard cohesion policy.
What steps does the Commission intend to take with a

view to defining the future borders of the European Union?

2062,9,580,en,Research and development,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

Currently the European Union's 25 members spend
about £120 billion a year investing in research and
development. Compared with more than £210 billion spent by the

is one of the factors contributing to a 'brain drain' of scientific
talent from Europe to the US. The Kok report noted that nearly
three-quarters of the world's leading IT companies were from the US.

Education in July 2004 on German regional aid (EU and German federal
programmes) shows that up to 96% of the appropriations paid in
subsidies have no lasting impact in economic terms owing to
geographical relocations and the deadweight effect. The current
proposal for a regulation laying down general provisions
(COM(2004)0492 final) seeks to prevent subsidies being paid for
business relocation during the new programming period. However, this
scheme relates only to the 7-year period during which the subsidised
investment has to remain in a given location. How will it be possible
for the relocation of a business before that period to be taken into
account under this scheme? How would it be possible to prevent

subsidies being used solely for relocation?

2071,9,550,en,Inspections to monitor implementation of environmental legislation,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

legislation in Greece and other EU countries, which cause
environmental pollution and lead to time-consuming procedures, in

authorities only carry out inspections and controls at the project

implementation of environmental legislation in the Member States and
make compulsory regular inspections and controls throughout the

(NB The Luxembourg Presidency talked about Aid Battle Groups during
the exchange of views in the Foreign Affairs Committee on 19 January

charge of administrative reform of the European institutions.

clarity? What methods of communication does it intend to use to get

stressed the strategic importance of Ukraine as a neighbour and
partner of the EU and expressed its wish that cooperation with that
country should be strengthened after the free and democratic election
of a new president. On 17 December 2004, the European Council
expressed its wish for the gradual intensification and strengthening
of political and economic relations between the EU and Ukraine. The

appointment as a Commissioner, Mrs Reding said that promoting digital
literacy would be one of her priorities. However, so far most of the
measures to overcome the digital divide have only concerned access to
communications technologies rather than promoting actual digital
skills.

objectives of the information society was to change the approach from
'access to technology for all' to 'making the necessary information
and skills available to all'.

considerably enhance people's work. In view of the above, what will

knowledge available to all' and increase digital literacy in the

",1991-04-16,draft,question

to discuss European values leading to the publication of a report
entitled ‘Europe - a good idea’, education being one of the five

emphasised the importance of incorporating within the education

intended that they would be implemented at national level so as to

come to be guided by the principles of freedom, solidarity and mutual

",2002-01-02,draft,question

development. Sport can bring benefits both to individuals, who can
enjoy participating in healthier activities, and wider communities as
it can often build better relations. Sports, thanks to global
cost-cutting capacities in human development can add tremendous
positive value to international work' (Adolf Ogi, the UN
Secretary-General's Special Adviser on Sport for Development and
2005 is the United Nations International Year of
Sport and Physical Education. Sport and physical education are
considered to be means to promote education, health, development and
peace. One of the goals of the International Year is to create the
right conditions for more sport-based development programmes and
projects. Several countries, for example Norway, Canada, United
Kingdom and the Netherlands, are active in this field. Sport projects
apparently can contribute to reaching the MDGs, especially on themes
like health, education, gender, environment and peace. They are also

stimulates countries and international sports associations to be
active in this field through assisting in capacity building,
recognising the possible contribution of sport to social cohesion,
intercultural dialogues, environmental understanding and
re-integration of children in post-conflict situations and the

physical education can contribute to development and to reaching the

programmes and projects? Can the Council stimulate a study on the
results of projects that have been realised by development
organisations and sport organisations on development and sport, the
potential of policy in this field and the possible role for the EU

and/or the Member States and/or NGOs on development and sport?

The European Union has expressly recognised the
importance and usefulness of homeopathic medicines and has regulated
their placing on the market by means of a number of directives, the
most recent of which is Directive 2004/27/EC(1), which amends the
Community code relating to medicinal products for human use
(Directive 2001/83/EC(2)).
Italy officially transposed that directive by means
of Decree Law 219/2006, Chapter 2 of which lays down special
provisions applying to homeopathic medicines, including the option,
as required under EC law, to use a simplified procedure to register
some homeopathic medicines (for oral administration/external
use/without therapeutic indications and with a given degree of
dilution).
However, Article 17 of Decree Law 219/2006 required
the publication in the Official Gazette, within three months of the
decree law's entry into force, of a specimen registration application
form drawn up by the AIFA (Italian Medicines Agency). Inexplicably,
that form, the contents of which were specified in the transposing
act, has, several years later, still to be published. This situation
constitutes an inadmissible barrier to implementation of the
provisions of Directive 2004/27/EC.
Some nine million Italians use homeopathic
medicines, and the failure to publish the above form has, in
practice, made it impossible to place new homeopathic medicines on
the market, thus seriously damaging the interests of both producers
and consumers.
Given the above, and with a view to ensuring that EU
citizens are free to choose treatments and producers are able to
develop new products, would the Commission state whether:
1. it is aware of the above issue
2. it intends to take steps to put an end to this
situation, which is hampering the establishment of a harmonised
internal market and causing serious damage to European producers and

consumers?

In April 2007, I tabled questions concerning the
e-Borders Programme, which has existed in the UK since 2004
(reference: E-2115/07).
As a follow-up to those questions I would like to
inform the Commission about the latest developments in this
programme, in particular in the aviation sector. The UK authorities
are requiring air carriers to participate in the e-Borders Programme
by providing advance passenger information (API). From the last
quarter of 2009 onwards, for designated routes (which might include
intra-EU flights), carriers will be obliged to provide the UK
authorities with even more data – what is termed ‘other passenger
information’ (OPI), also known as passenger name records (PNR) –
data routinely held in carrier reservation systems, in so far as they
are known to them.
1. Does the Commission agree that, as there has been
no decision yet regarding the EU PNR proposal (COM(2007)654), the
request for OPI (PNR) data by the UK is premature? If not, why not?
Both Directive 2004/82/EC1 and the EU PNR proposal
are very clear in stating that disclosure of passenger data by air
carriers concerns only ‘international flights’ (i.e. from outside
the EU). The ‘new’ UK plans are not clear at all as to whether or
not they will require ‘intra-EU’ passenger data. This is leading
to great uncertainty for the aviation sector on what it can expect
from EU Member States regarding an obligation to disclose
passenger-related data (API, OPI, PNR, and credit card data, even
though this type of data is no longer part of PNR, and/or departure
control systems (DCS)).
2. Would the Commission be willing to look into the
UK situation in greater depth, in particular concerning the
consequences of this programme for the free movement of persons in
the EU? If so, could the Commission inform me about its findings? If
not, why not?
Each new disclosure or new type of disclosure
requires investment in a number of areas (system adjustments,
procedural changes, data communication costs) by the aviation sector.
As the economic situation in the aviation sector is currently very
weak, that investment might lead to serious financial problems and/or
bankruptcy.
3. Does the Commission agree that this investment
imposes a disproportionate burden on the aviation sector? If not, why

not?

At the end of January, the Heartland Payment
Systems credit card processing company revealed that its files had
been breached. It appears that unknown hackers had managed to
infiltrate its systems in 2008 and install malicious software
enabling them to steal credit card data and thereby make copies of up
to 100 million cards. Given that Heartland Payment Systems is the
sixth largest credit card processing company in the USA, it is clear
that similar breaches could easily occur in smaller European
undertakings. In view of the fact that most Europeans make Internet
purchases, what measures are being taken to protect their credit card
data from expert hackers? What action has been taken by the
Commission in the past, and what action does it intend to take in

",2007-08-04,draft,question
2113,9,562,en,‘Emergency travel document’,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

TD P { margin-bottom: 0in }

More and more European citizens travel to
non-EU countries. If their passport is lost or stolen, the only way
to travel back to the EU is to acquire an ‘emergency travel
document’ from their own national embassy or consulate, and if
those do not exist then they should be able to obtain the document
from any other embassy or consulate of a Member State on the spot
(Article 20 TEC). This ‘emergency travel document’ was created 12
years ago by Council Decision 96/409(1). However, organisations of
expatriate EU citizens complain about the difficulties EU citizens
have when travelling back due to the border authorities'
unwillingness to accept this document.
I would like to know:
1. Is this ‘emergency travel document’
also valid for transit to other EU countries through major hubs
located outside the Schengen area (for example London Heathrow)?
2. How are the EU external borders
authorities made aware of the existence of this ‘emergency travel
document’, and what measures has the Commission taken until now in
order to inform them?
3. Is this ‘emergency travel document’
going to be published in the handbook for EU border guards, with a
picture so the authorities will be aware of it?
4. Will this ‘emergency travel document’
acquire biometrics and security features, as in the national EU

passports it is supposed to replace?

",2003-01-15,draft,question
2118,9,588,en,European Year of Equal Opportunities for All (2007),,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

In its proposal for a decision of the EP and
the Council concerning the European Year of Equal Opportunities for
All (2007), the Commission states that the Year will seek to
highlight the message to the public at large that all people,
irrespective of their sex, racial or ethnic origin, religion or
belief, disability, age and sexual orientation, are entitled to equal
treatment. Promoting respect and tolerance is high on the agenda.
According to the proposal, all manner of policy measures and
initiatives are required in order to promote greater participation of
under-represented groups in society. Besides support for national
initiatives and measures, all manner of ‘Community level action’
is promised, such as information and promotion campaigns
As numerous studies indicate, many Islamic
women suffer discrimination by and in their (Islamic) community and
this hampers their full participation in the labour market and
society in general.
As a study by Professor Werner Bergmann of
Berlin University of Technology dating from 2002 showed, anti-Semitic
acts are committed primarily by young Muslims, many of them of Arab
origin.
How will the Commission approach these
serious problems in its campaign? Will it launch a specific campaign
to make it clear to the Islamic community that women should enjoy
equal rights and opportunities? How will the Commission persuade
Islamic communities in Europe to display greater respect and

tolerance towards Jewish communities?

States, as well as a founding Member State, Italian is not included
among the ‘procedural languages’, but is treated as a lesser
language, as if the Union's 60 million Italians were less important
than the citizens of France, Germany and the United Kingdom, whose
populations are comparable to that of Italy — except for Germany,
which has a somewhat larger population.
The supposedly ‘pragmatic’ mechanism
adopted by the Commission for using the official languages of the
Member States totally contradicts the very nature of the European

criteria, as is the custom among civilised countries that respect the
rule of law.
Can the Commission say:

French and German were chosen as procedural languages
2. according to what criteria Italian was

excluded in this context?

",1988-02-01,draft,question
2127,9,557,en,EU staff settling on the outskirts of Brussels,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

TD P { margin-bottom: 0in }

Experience shows that the majority of EU
officials now working in Brussels choose to live in one of the 19
municipalities of the Brussels capital region or on the outskirts of
Brussels. However, particularly in the latter area, which is part of
the Flemish and therefore Dutch-speaking region, a number of problems
arise. There are problems of a social nature (the large presence of
EU officials in some municipalities is inflating rents and property
prices, as a result of which many young Flemish families are forced
to leave their local area), but also problems of language policy.
Many Flemish suburban municipalities have to cope with the problem of
French-speaking Belgian incomers who refuse to recognise the
Dutch-speaking character of the area. The gradual Frenchification of
parts of Flemish Brabant is a significant political problem. In a
number of municipalities (so-called municipalities with facilities)
the original Flemish inhabitants have already become a minority. The
presence of large numbers of EU staff who cannot speak Dutch has
often exacerbated the problems. Not because of any ill will on the
part of these EU officials, but mostly for other reasons such as lack
of information.
There are ways of tackling these problems.
New or even existing EU officials could be offered incentives to
settle in neighbouring Walloon Brabant. They could also be made aware
of the political situation in the outskirts of Brussels, and
encouraged to take the Dutch language courses organised by the
municipalities, and so on.
Is the Commission, unlike former
Commissioner Neil Kinnock, prepared to examine these and possibly
other measures to make the process of EU staff taking up residence
and settling in the area around Brussels go more smoothly?

",2005-03-14,draft,question
2137,9,579,en,Formation of European Companies,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

The European Company Statute is a new legal
instrument for undertakings, albeit one which has still to be
perfected, and a political step forward for Europe.
Following the technical measures taken at
national level, in France it has been possible, in practical terms,
to form a European Company since June 2005. However, over a 12-month
period not one application for the registration of a European Company
was lodged on French territory.
A wide range of criticisms have been voiced,
as regards both the substance of the Statute (lack of any specific
tax provisions) and the administrative arrangements (excessive delays
resulting from the institutions' slow working methods).
In the area of taxation, an immense amount
of work has still to be done. No Member State must lose sight of the
fact that a European Company can register in another State. For
example, in fiscal terms it is much more attractive for an
undertaking to register in Ireland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands or
Denmark than in France. France has a lot to lose in the light of its
territorial tax system, something which is becoming the exception in
Europe.
Article 69 of the regulation on the European
Company Statute stipulated that, at the latest five years after its
entry into force, the Commission would submit to Parliament a report
on the application of the regulation and, if appropriate, proposed
modifications.
Has the Commission grasped the extent of
this failure? How does it explain it? In the light of this failure,
does it plan to bring forward the submission of its report on the
application of the regulation, with a view to presenting proposed
modifications as soon as possible? What approach might offer a way
out of the fiscal impasse which is the inevitable result of differing

tax systems?

",2000-03-09,draft,question
2130,9,537,en,Awarding of projects to consultancy firms,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

During the debate of 25 November 2005 in the
Greek Parliament, the opposition denounced the fact that the Greek
Finance Ministry (YPOIKO) had awarded projects financed from the EU
Structural Funds and Cohesion Fund directly to consultancy firms. The
projects concerned (technical consultancy studies or services) were
awarded after the various economic topics had been divided up, using
procedures which have been described as subterfuge (cursory
competitions, for example). At the same time, it appears that the
selection of the technical consultants for the 13 Greek regions is to
be completed in 2006. This would make it pointless to recruit a large
number of consultants whose work will no longer be relevant to the
current programming period.
Which projects were awarded to consultancy
firms by the Finance Ministry in 2004 and 2005, either directly or
through cursory competitions? What are the names of the firms which
were awarded projects, what prices were stipulated in the contracts
and when exactly were the projects awarded? What was the
justification for the Finance Ministry's use of fast-track procedures
in each individual case? From which Community funds and operational
programmes are these projects financed? When were they included in
the programme, who is the final beneficiary and/or implementing body,
and what is the total amount of appropriations assigned to this
expenditure (for each final beneficiary) in 2005 and 2006? In what
way is it expedient to continue with the procedure for recruiting
technical consultants in the 13 regions when it has already been

",1996-05-12,draft,question
2133,9,532,en,Draft Act No 6229 of the Italian Chamber of Deputies,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

Draft Act No 6229, which was definitively
adopted by the Italian Chamber of Deputies on 24 January 2006, lays
down provisions governing the nursing, obstetrics, rehabilitation,
medical technology and preventative healthcare professions and
delegates to the Italian Government responsibility for instituting
the relative professional associations. That Act sets itself the
objective of ensuring that these associations are established.
This will lead to the setting-up, for
example, of professional associations for biomedical laboratory
technicians, physiotherapists, preventative health experts and speech
therapists, etc.
This clearly conflicts with the principles
of free movement, with Directive 2005/36/EC(1) on the recognition of
professional qualifications and with the explicit calls made to Italy
to abolish professional associations definitively.
Moreover, the Italian Senate has already
adopted Draft Act No 6293, Article 1(f) of which places the
profession of physiotherapist on a par with that of gymnastics
teacher (graduate in motor science), thereby bracketing together two
completely different professions.
In the light of the above, can the
Commission indicate what action it will take to ensure that Italy

abides by the rules in force?

",2005-12-02,draft,question
2138,9,581,en,National Centre for European Information and Documentation — CIDE,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html
<style type=""text/css"">

By law of 23 June 2003 No 178, the Italian
Government was authorised to sign an agreement with the European
Commission to establish the National Centre for European Information
and Documentation — CIDE. This body was set up, in the form of a
European Economic Interest Grouping (EEIG), in March 2001 for the
purpose of providing information, documentation, training and other
services for Italian citizens relating to European Union policy
issues, mainly through initiatives for the general public. By
decision of 28 November 2005, the Commission announced that, on
expiry of the current contract (April 2007), it would not be able to
extend its direct involvement as a member of the EEIG in currently
existing National Information Centres on the EU (including in France
and Portugal) because this had become technically incompatible with
the provisions of its new financial regulation. However, it plans to
offer alternative forms of cooperation, based on ‘management
partnerships’, which could continue to co-finance the activities
and projects of a CIDE-type national centre.
At a time when all EU Member States are
maintaining that they wish to step up efforts to bring citizens
closer to the process of European integration and are acknowledging
their duty to cooperate with the European institutions in improving
communication on EU policy decisions in order to build up a genuine
European public opinion, Italy seems to think that it can abandon the
sole general institutional and operational instrument with specific
powers and mechanisms that can serve this purpose.
Is the Commission prepared to review its
decision?
Can the Commission explain what it means by
the term ‘management partnerships’? How can it ensure that
experience and professional skills that have been acquired are not

lost?

",2003-04-04,draft,question
2131,9,553,en,The Commission's views on cooperation between local authorities,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html
<style type=""text/css"">
@page { size: 8.27in 11.69in

At a workshop organised by the Council of
European Municipalities and Regions (CCRE) on 29 September 2005, Mr
Rein of the Internal Market DG said that public procurement law was
applicable to all forms of written agreement between public
authorities involving any kind of valuable consideration or quid pro
quo.
It is therefore becoming increasingly
unclear in what cases local authorities still have the right to
entrust a task to an inter-authority organisation set up by
themselves, as the Commission evidently takes the view that public
procurement law must always be applied. An article published in
‘Lokaal’ — a publication of the Flemish Union of Local
Authorities (VVSG) — in November 2005 concludes from this that the
Commission virtually never regards cooperation between local
authorities as an in-house award of a contract, because a number of
local authorities are involved and therefore it is not possible to
exercise control in the same way as in relation to their own
departments. In taking this view, the Commission goes further than
the Teckal judgment, which refers to similar control. The same
article also states that the Commission has for some considerable
time been investigating all forms of cooperation between local
authorities, including autonomous municipal undertakings in Belgium.
The following questions therefore arise:
— What is the state of play in the
investigation into cooperation between local authorities in Belgium?
— To what extent does the
Commission still consider cooperation between local authorities to be
possible without any violation of public procurement law?
— Why, in assessing such
cooperation, does the Commission adopt an even more restrictive

position than the Court of Justice?

",2006-02-27,draft,question
2134,9,556,en,Brussels IV European School,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

The answer I received from Commissioner
Kallas to my previous Written Question P-4955/05 is totally evasive,
unforthcoming and incomplete.
With reference to the criteria adopted by
the Board of Governors on 25-26 October 2005, I would like to know
how these are interpreted by the Commission, which is part both of
the Brussels IV follow-up group (Groupe de Suivi) established by the
Secretary-General of the European Schools, and of the Board of
Governors of the European Schools, which will have to decide in April
2005 what language sections will be sent to the Brussels IV school.
In view of this, I would again ask the
Commission what its interpretation is of criterion C. In other words,
does the Commission consider it possible to achieve a correct
geographical balance of language sections in the four Brussels
schools? How does the Commission propose to do this?
How does the Commission interpret criterion
F? In other words, looking at the map of Brussels, the centre of the
city and the locations of the four school sites, would the Commission
indicate which of these sites, in its opinion, can be considered
central and which peripheral?
Finally, with reference to the optimum
number of students per section, can the Commission specify which

that recommendation was made, and on the basis of what criteria,
given that the Board of Governors had previously taken as a guideline

a threshold of 159 students per language section?

",2007-08-13,draft,question
2139,9,581,en,Alleged EU budget deficit,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

It was alleged in the Financial Times of
London on 13 November 2006 by John Plender that since the publishing
of the European Communities 2005 annual accounts under the new
accruals basis a serious budget deficit has been uncovered which was
previously disguised when the accounts were published on a cash
basis.
He states that considering liabilities that
are due but for which no invoice or cost claims have yet been made
during the tenure of the previous President Prodi Commission, and
removing a questionable asset raised to reflect member states'
guarantee of the Commission staffs pensions, along with other smaller
adjustments, a EUR 14.5 billion surplus of net assets as was
previously reported now turns into a massive EUR 51.6 billion
deficit.
Can the Commission confirm these figures and
can it explain how it proposes to correct this deficit as the EU

financial perspective has been already fixed for 2007-13?

",2006-12-17,draft,question
2141,9,590,en,United Nations Development Programme,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

In a letter to the United Nations
Development Programme (UNDP) published by the Wall Street Journal
recently (http://opinionjournal.com/editorial/011907letter.pdf),
Ambassador Mark Wallace of the US Mission to the UN reveals that
since 1998 the UNDP programme in the Democratic People's Republic of
Korea (DPRK) ‘has been systematically perverted for the benefit of
the Kim Jong Il regime’.
Ambassador Wallace details that:
— UNDP pays cash to local DPRK
government suppliers, in violation of UNDP rules,
— UNDP funds DPRK-controlled
projects without oversight,
— UNDP pays all local staff
salaries directly to the DPRK government,
— all UNDP local expenditure and
procurements are paid in cash directly to the DPRK government.
According to the UNDP's 2006 annual report,
the European Commission provided USD 426.9 million to the UNDP in
How much money did the Commission provide
for 2006, and how much has the Commission committed for 2007?
In light of this scandal, will the
Commission suspend payments to the UNDP until the results of the
inquiry ordered by the UN Secretary-General are known?
Will the Commission also suspend all
payments, including co-financing and voluntary funding, to all UN
activities in North Korea pending the outcome of the system-wide

inquiry?

",2002-02-10,draft,question
2144,9,567,en,European ‘Green Card’,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html
<style type=""text/css"">
@page { size: 8.27in 11.69in
TD P { margin-bottom: 0in }
P { margin-bottom: 0.08in }
</style>
The brain drain from Europe and the
immigration of foreign graduates, proportionately and globally lower
than in Australia, Canada and the USA, is reducing Europe's research
capabilities and weakening its innovation capacity. This problem
needs to be looked at closely because 87 % of North Africans entering
the EU have had no higher education. The fact that 900 highly skilled
workers arrived in Germany in 2005 while some 22 000 German
professionals left the country to look for work abroad in the first
six months of 2006 should give us food for thought on the causes of
this phenomenon. Meanwhile, the number of skilled workers emigrating
to Australia has risen from 71 240 in 2003 to 97 000 in 2006. The
‘Green Card’ which the Commission is planning to introduce is, in
our view, an appropriate means of simplifying bureaucratic procedures
for the entry of highly skilled workers into the EU.
1. Does the Commission really believe that
the brain drain from the EU and the lack of immigration of highly
skilled personnel is due to bureaucratic complexities?
2. Does it not agree, instead, that it is
more a result of the constraints and corporatist forms of protection
and privileges preventing the recognition of merit and the
corresponding remuneration?
3. Does the Commission agree that, in
addition to a European ‘Green Card’ to combat bureaucratic
complications, other measures should be taken to liberalise
situations and remove the blocages in the way of labour market
processes and the recognition of suitable remuneration levels?
4. Does it not consider it appropriate to
reconsider the so-called ‘European social model’ (high
unemployment and low wages) in order to be able to compete on the
world market with those countries taking in an increasing number of

highly skilled workers?

",1999-11-06,draft,question
2145,9,568,en,The EU and multilingualism,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html
<style type=""text/css"">
@page { size: 8.27in 11.69in
TD P { margin-bottom: 0in }
P { margin-bottom: 0.08in }
</style>
The European Commissioner for
multilingualism — Leonard Orban — is to make an official visit to
Italy on 23 March of this year on the occasion of the 50th
anniversary of the signing of the Rome treaties. For the first time
the sole content of a European Commissioner's portfolio is
responsibility for multilingualism — testimony to the increasing
importance attached by the EU to acknowledging and encouraging the
languages spoken in the Member States. Providing the people of Europe
with access to information concerning the EU in their own language is
a crucial step towards the full establishment of European
citizenship. It is to be hoped that the Commission will honour the
commitments it made in its November 2005 Communication (which serves
to promote multilingualism within European society, the economic
sphere and the Commission itself) and that it will set a good
example.
In this connection and in view of the fact
that a Commission representative has been appointed in order to
tackle the challenges of multilingualism, will the Commission say
whether it considers it justifiable that documents intended for all
EU citizens (such as the websites and in particular information
documents, with the sole exception of official announcements and
communications referring to European programmes) should be available
in only two or three languages, thereby restricting access by many
small local bodies to EU funding?
This is a reference in particular to guides
for candidates, to the full texts of invitations to tender (which
contain all the information concerning specifications and the
criteria for tendering a bid) and to all the various forms needed for
the purpose of submitting a proposal. One representative example: the
application documents relating to the Lingua programme (which is
designed to promote multilingualism) exist only in English, French
and German.
Is the Commission intending to remedy this
state of affairs (and, if so, how?), which severely hampers full
involvement by local bodies in European political life and European
initiatives, including the provision of funding?
The author of this question does not regard
Reply E-1120/06 (given in May 2006 by Mrs Grybauskaitė on behalf of
the Commission) as fully satisfactory, since it does not address the
issue of making the documents needed for the purpose of submitting
tenders under EU programmes available in all the languages, so as to

ensure that all EU citizens have the same opportunities.

strict, depending on how European Parliament and Council Directive
2005/29/EC(1) of 11 May 2005 on Unfair Commercial Practices is

an operator in each Member State, is Apple infringing Directive
2. Will the Commission ask Apple to explain

Directive 2004/54/EC(1), on minimum safety
requirements for tunnels in the Trans-European Road Network, was
published in April 2004. It stipulates, inter alia, that states have
responsibility for inspecting tunnels, as a result of Parliament and
the Council having demanded the full application of the principle of
subsidiarity and delegated to the national Authorities full
responsibility for conducting inspections in the specific area of
tunnel safety.
However, it has been announced on various
occasions that the Commission will fund a ‘EuroTAP’ project, to
be launched in January 2005, with the aim of carrying out practical
monitoring of safety in road tunnels through safety tests on such
tunnels in the Union whose findings will be made available to
consumers and widely publicised.
The scheme as a whole is based on a system
of assessment of the potential safety risk and service provided by
tunnels, applied unilaterally by the project.
In the light of the aforementioned
provisions of Directive 2004/54/EC, will the Commission answer the
following questions:
— Why is funding being provided
from the Community budget for an activity whose aims appear
potentially harmful to the prerogatives of Member States and to
interfere with specific competences conferred by Directive 2004/54/EC
to inspection bodies, tunnel administrators, safety authorities,
etc.?
— Secondly, what red line does the
Commission intend to impose in order to ensure that ‘monitoring’
does not turn into ‘inspection’, and what criteria does it
believe should be applied in the implementation of the project, aimed
at informing consumers, with respect to the more general aims pursued
by Directive 2004/54/EC, relating to traffic safety and, hence, to

the protection of road users?

",2003-07-30,draft,question
2153,9,562,en,Legal basis for lesser-used languages,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html

All European languages, regardless of how
widely spoken they are, form part of Europe's rich cultural heritage
which must be scrupulously respected and fostered. In this context,
the Ebner report on regional and lesser-used European languages
(2003/2057(INI)) made a number of valuable recommendations to the
Commission with the aim of increasing the support given to such
languages.
The resolution adopted by Parliament
advocated, inter alia, that a new budget item be established in the
course of the annual budgetary procedure with the corresponding
appropriations to finance a multiannual programme for linguistic
diversity, including ‘regional, minority and sign languages’,
with a new legal basis. However, the Commission has made no provision
for creating this new item in its preliminary draft budget for 2005.
Will the Commission shortly be proposing a
new legal basis allowing substantial funds to be earmarked for
promoting lesser-used languages?
The Ebner report likewise proposed the
creation of a European Agency for Linguistic Diversity and Language
Learning, which would also deal with ‘minority’ languages.
Will the Commission propose the creation of

this agency in the near future, as called for by Parliament?

",2003-07-14,draft,question
2158,9,590,en,Stability and Growth Pact,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html
<style type=""text/css"">
@page { size: 8.27in 11.69in
TD P { margin-bottom: 0in }
P { margin-bottom: 0.08in }
</style>
On 3 September 2004 the Commission adopted a
communication, which among other issues dealt with the Stability and
Growth Pact (SGP) and measures that can be taken, to make SGP more
effective. More specifically, Commissioner Joaquín Almunia
announced that ‘the Commission intends to push forward this debate
in an open and transparent manner and in close cooperation with
Member States. Our proposals introduce more economic rationale in the
implementation of the Stability and Growth Pact while strengthening
surveillance and enforcement.’ (Press release IP/04/1062).
On 14 December 2004 the Commission lifted
all sanctions against France and Germany, the eurozone's two biggest
economies, over breaches of the 3% budget deficit ceiling - despite
fears that Germany at least will fail to comply next year for the
fourth consecutive year. Specifically, RWI, one of Germany's six
leading economic institutes, forecasted that the country's budget
deficit would be 3.4% in 2005, as it cut its growth estimate from
1.5% to 1.3% and warned that the outcome could be even lower if the
dollar continued its slide against the euro.
Is the decision taken by the Commission on
14 December a reflection of what Commissioner Almunia considers to be
transparency and strengthening of the enforcement of the SGP?
How is the Commission prepared to react in a
similar case (2-3 years not meeting SGP criteria) if a country with a
considerably smaller economy than Germany or France is involved? Will
that country have the same treatment as Germany and France or will a

discriminatory policy be pursued against that country?

",1999-11-16,draft,question
2154,9,579,en,Decentralised agencies,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html
<style type=""text/css"">
@page { size: 8.27in 11.69in
TD P { margin-bottom: 0in }
P { margin-bottom: 0.08in }
</style>
Under the principles of European governance
providing for less direct administration by the Commission, more
effective controls on results and a better cost-benefit ratio, a
large number of decentralised agencies have been set up. There are 23
at present, and another five are proposed in the Commission's draft
budget for 2005.
The increasing number of agencies (in 1990
there were only three) has led to much higher levels of expenditure,
as normally entered under heading 3 of the financial perspective
(internal policies) - rising from EUR 96 m in 2000 to an expected EUR
This has a substantial impact on heading 3
and risks jeopardising the other policies and programmes under that
heading.
It is therefore essential to ensure the
highest possible levels of transparency and monitoring in respect of
the agencies' expenditure. It is equally vital to operate a carefully
planned personnel policy, taking account of the Staff Regulations and
of the need to ensure a geographical balance of human resources and
maximum effectiveness in achieving the objectives set.
In view of the above:
1. What is the Commission's evaluation of
the situation?
2. What initiatives have been taken to
ensure respect for transparency, planning and the effectiveness of
action of the individual agencies?
3. What actions will the Commission take to
ensure that the public and private sectors in the Union can derive

maximum benefit from the work of the agencies?

2155,9,588,en,State aid measures for technology and business centres,,"<meta http-equiv=""CONTENT-TYPE"" content=""text/html
